G.L. c. 186.proposition: Upon information and belief, Defendant Samantha Baker is an individual who owns and/or manages the residential property located at 24–26 Elm Street, Roxbury, Massachusetts 02119, and is Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord “shall not directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant,” and any landlord who does so is liable for actual and consequential damages or for three months’ rent, whichever is greater, together with costs and reasonable attorneys’ fees.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7\u00a7 2, 3.proposition: The Boston Housing Court Department has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, §§ 2, 3, because this is a civil action involving the residential premises located in Boston/Roxbury and arises out of the landlord‑tenant relationship.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: The recurring water intrusion and excessive moisture have rendered the Premises excessively damp, unsanitary, and unhealthy to occupy, in violation of the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including but not limited to 105 C.M.R. 410.500 et seq. (structural elements, protection from water and weather) and 105 C.M.R. 410.750 (conditions deemed to endanger or impair health or safety).

105 C.M.R. 410.500 et seq..proposition: The recurring water intrusion and excessive moisture have rendered the Premises excessively damp, unsanitary, and unhealthy to occupy, in violation of the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including but not limited to 105 C.M.R. 410.500 et seq. (structural elements, protection from water and weather) and 105 C.M.R. 410.750 (conditions deemed to endanger or impair health or safety).

105 C.M.R. 410.750.proposition: The recurring water intrusion and excessive moisture have rendered the Premises excessively damp, unsanitary, and unhealthy to occupy, in violation of the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including but not limited to 105 C.M.R. 410.500 et seq. (structural elements, protection from water and weather) and 105 C.M.R. 410.750 (conditions deemed to endanger or impair health or safety).

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A\u2013127L.proposition: Plaintiff engaged in protected activity by contacting the city for an inspection concerning unsanitary and unsafe conditions at the Premises, which is activity expressly contemplated and protected by Massachusetts landlord‑tenant law and policy.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 2A.proposition: Plaintiff engaged in protected activity by contacting the city for an inspection concerning unsanitary and unsafe conditions at the Premises, which is activity expressly contemplated and protected by Massachusetts landlord‑tenant law and policy.

Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.proposition: Defendant, as landlord, has at all times owed Plaintiff the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment guaranteed by G.L. c. 186, § 14, as well as the common‑law covenant of quiet enjoyment implied in residential leases in Massachusetts. See, e.g., Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33 (1929).
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.support_reasoning: The case recognizes an implied covenant that the lessor will refrain from acts that substantially impair the character and value of the leased premises, and discusses wrongful interference with a tenant’s enjoyment. However, it does not mention or interpret G.L. c. 186, § 14, nor does it frame the landlord’s obligations as a “statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment.” The authority here is for the common‑law implied covenant and related tort/nuisance principles, not for a statutory covenant owed “at all times” under § 14.
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.relevant_excerpt: “The lease carried with it an implication that the lessors would refrain from acts voluntarily undertaken which substantially ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … The same act may be a breach of the covenant for quiet enjoyment and also a wrong causing injury to the tenant for which injunctive relief might be sought or an action of tort would lie.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.proposition: To establish a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, a tenant need not show an actual or constructive eviction, but only that the landlord’s acts or omissions caused a substantial interference with the tenant’s tenancy. See Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716–18 (1977).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and constructive eviction, and makes clear that the landlord’s liability turns on conduct (acts or omissions) that naturally and probably causes substantial interference, rather than on intent. However, in this case the tenants actually did vacate and the court repeatedly characterizes the situation as a constructive eviction and affirms judgments on that basis. The court does not clearly state that a tenant may prevail on a quiet enjoyment claim without showing actual or constructive eviction; it simply does not frame the rule in those distinct terms, so using this case for that specific proposition is somewhat overstated.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Although some of our opinions have spoken of particular action or inaction by a landlord as showing a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983–84 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: A landlord’s failure to remedy serious sanitary code and water infiltration conditions after notice can constitute an “indirect interference” with tenants’ quiet enjoyment in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14. See Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983–84 (1982); Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907, 908–09 (1987).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion holds that failure to provide heat—required by the State Sanitary Code—constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but it does not involve or discuss water infiltration or a broader set of serious sanitary code violations. The case is good authority that failure to provide essential heat after notice is an actionable interference with quiet enjoyment; extending it to ‘serious sanitary code and water infiltration conditions’ is an extrapolation not directly addressed in the opinion. Thus, it only partially matches the stated proposition and does not support it as written.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “The tenant correctly argues that the judge erred in declaring that the landlords’ financial inability to purchase oil constituted a defense to the quiet enjoyment claim. A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season…seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’…and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.… [L]iability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907, 908–09 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: A landlord’s failure to remedy serious sanitary code and water infiltration conditions after notice can constitute an “indirect interference” with tenants’ quiet enjoyment in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14. See Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983–84 (1982); Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907, 908–09 (1987).
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion in Young v. Patukonis, as excerpted, does not discuss G.L. c. 186, § 14 or the concept of “indirect interference” with quiet enjoyment. The decision addresses sanitary code violations only in the context of a warranty of habitability/rent abatement claim and finds most conditions had minimal impact, without linking them to a statutory quiet enjoyment violation. Because there is no analysis or holding that a landlord’s failure to remedy serious sanitary code and water infiltration conditions after notice constitutes an indirect interference with quiet enjoyment, the case does not support the specific proposition cited.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: “Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property. The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs.”

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 198–203 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Serious code violations that affect health and safety give rise to a breach of the implied warranty of habitability and may also support a claim for breach of quiet enjoyment. See Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 198–203 (1973).
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: This excerpt is from Justice Quirico’s separate concurrence/dissent, not the majority, and it focuses on contract interdependence and how to conceptualize an implied obligation (warranty vs. implied covenant) based on code compliance. It does not clearly state that serious code violations affecting health and safety give rise to an implied warranty of habitability, nor does it discuss or ground a claim for breach of quiet enjoyment. The majority opinion in Hemingway is often cited for those propositions, but this specific passage does not itself provide that authority.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”}

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 789–90 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.proposition: Defendant’s prolonged inaction and failure to repair after notice constitute an indirect but substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the Premises under G.L. c. 186, § 14. See Lowery, 13 Mass. App. Ct. at 983–84; Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 789–90 (1994).
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.support_reasoning: The opinion directly holds that a landlord’s failure to repair known defects, after notice, constitutes an "omission" that can violate G.L. c. 186, § 14 when it substantially impairs the value of the premises, and emphasizes that the landlord’s conduct, not intent, is controlling. Applying that rule, the SJC found that Cruz Management’s prolonged failure adequately to correct serious code violations, despite notice and attempted but ineffectual repairs, showed a violation of § 14. This aligns with the proposition that prolonged inaction and failure to repair after notice is an indirect but substantial interference with quiet enjoyment.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.relevant_excerpt: Decisions from this court and from the Appeals Court clearly support the imposition of civil liability under § 14 in circumstances like those present in this case. In Ianello v. Court Management Corp., 400 Mass. 321, 323 (1987), it was said that a landlord violates § 14 when his acts or omissions impair the value of the leased premises. … A landlord’s failure to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14. … Cruz Management had notice of numerous sanitary, building and fire code violations… [and] a violation of § 14 has been shown.

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285–86 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Additionally, retaliatory conduct in response to a tenant’s reporting of code violations and seeking enforcement of sanitary and housing laws can itself be deemed an interference with quiet enjoyment. See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285–86 (1994); Cruz Mgmt. Co., 417 Mass. at 790–91.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion recognizes that serious interference with tenants’ use of common areas caused by third-party criminal activity may breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment when it is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did or failed to do. However, it does not involve, discuss, or characterize *retaliatory* conduct by the landlord in response to tenants’ reporting of code violations or seeking enforcement of sanitary or housing laws. The case is about failure to address drug activity, not retaliation for protected complaints, so it does not support the specific retaliatory-conduct proposition stated.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 186, § 14, provides, in relevant part, that ‘any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant’ shall be punished by a fine or imprisonment, and also shall be subject to liability to the tenant for damages arising from the interference… a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’”

Spence v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Spence v. O’Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 489, 491–95 (1983)
Spence v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that landlord retaliation against a tenant for complaints to authorities about housing conditions is unlawful and can support claims under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and related doctrines. See, e.g., Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. at 285–86; Spence v. O’Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 489, 491–95 (1983).
Spence v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion is an eviction case about drug activity in a public housing unit and focuses on ‘good cause’ for termination, tenant responsibility for a co-occupant’s misconduct, notice requirements, and availability of defenses under G.L. c. 239, § 8A. It does not discuss landlord retaliation, tenant complaints about housing conditions, or G.L. c. 186, § 14. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the proposition that Massachusetts recognizes retaliation for housing-condition complaints as unlawful under c. 186, § 14 or related doctrines.
Spence v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt:
O’Brien argues that the trial judge was in error in refusing to allow her to raise the defense of uninhabitable conditions under G. L. c. 239, § 8A. She concedes that these defenses cannot be raised where an eviction is based upon wrongdoing, or fault, by the tenant. She argues, however, that her eviction was based upon cause and not fault and that she can, therefore, assert uninhabitable conditions.

While cause may not always involve fault by a tenant, cause “is a general term, and must take on much of its meaning from the context in which it is used.” Spence v. Gormley, 387 Mass. at 263.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: Such substantial impairment constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, regardless of whether there has yet been an actual eviction or formal termination of the tenancy. See Blackett, 371 Mass. at 717–18; Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102–05 (1982).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The court explicitly interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14’s “quiet enjoyment” clause by reference to the common-law covenant of quiet enjoyment and emphasizes that liability turns on serious interferences that “impair the character and value of the leased premises,” not on eviction or formal termination. It holds Gem liable under § 14 for repeated flooding that substantially interfered with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the apartment, without any requirement of actual eviction, thereby supporting the proposition that substantial impairment alone constitutes a breach under § 14.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. … When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ … it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute… [Gem] permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.raw_text: Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761–62 (1979)
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, Plaintiff is entitled to recover his actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, plus court costs and reasonable attorneys’ fees. See, e.g., Cruz Mgmt. Co., 417 Mass. at 789–91; Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761–62 (1979).
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion directly interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14, and explains the statutory measure of damages: a landlord who interferes with quiet enjoyment is liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, plus costs and a reasonable attorney’s fee. The court rejects the trial judge’s miscalculation but affirms this statutory damages structure and the mandatory award of attorney’s fees and costs, squarely supporting the proposition.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 provides that a lessor who commits any act in violation of that section (including interference ‘with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises’) shall ‘be liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.’ … Section 14 allows a minimum recovery of three months’ rent as an incentive to the pursuit of relief where the actual and consequential damages are slight or are difficult to prove.”
